translated: As It Was Said

analyzed: catukka nipāta  brāhmaṇa dhamma yāga vagga
translated: The Fours🔽The Chapter on the Spiritual Life of the Holy Ones
Monks and Brahmins

analyzed: vuttam ha etam bhagavatā vuttam arahatā iti me suta
translated: This was said by the Blessed One, the One who is accomplished, the Fully Enlightened One. This I heard:🔽“Monks, there are monks and brahmins who do not understand as it really is:

original: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānanti;🔽‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānanti; ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā idam dukkhanti yathābhūtam na pajānanti  ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam na ppajānanti ayam dukkha nirodho ti yathābhūta
translated: ‘This is suffering.’

analyzed: na ppajānanti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati yathābhūtam na ppajānanti
translated: They do not understand as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering.’ They do not understand as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering.’ They do not understand as it really is: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

original: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā
analyzed: na me te bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā samaṇesu vā samaṇa sammatāḥ brāhmaṇesu vā
translated: Monks, those monks and brahmins are not true ascetics or brahmins.

original: brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca panete āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṁ vā brahmaññatthaṁ vā diṭṭheva🔽dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
analyzed: brāhmaṇa sammatāḥ na ca pana ete āyasmanto sāmañña ttham vā brahmañña ttham vā diṭṭhā iva  dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti
translated: They do not live the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama, nor have they reached the goal of the spiritual life.

original: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānanti;
analyzed: ye ca kho keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā idam dukkhanti yathābhūtam pajānanti
translated: Monks, there are monks and brahmins who understand as it really is: ‘This is suffering.’

analyzed: ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānanti ayam dukkha nirodho iti yathābhūta
translated: they understand as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering’; they understand as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering’;

analyzed: pajānanti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati yathābhūtam pajānanti
translated: They understand as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering.’ They understand as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering.’ They understand as it really is: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

original: te kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu🔽ca brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme
analyzed: te kho me bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā samaṇesu ca iva samaṇa sammatāḥ brāhmaṇesu  ca brāhmaṇa sammatā te ca pana āyasmanto sāmañña ttham ca brahmañña ttham ca diṭṭhe iva dhamme
translated: They are ascetics among ascetics and brahmins among brahmins.

original: sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.🔽Etamatthaṁ bhagavā avoca.
analyzed: sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti iti  etam attham bhagavān avoca
translated: They are worthy of gifts, worthy of hospitality, worthy of offerings, worthy of reverential salutation, an unsurpassed field of merit for the world.”🔽The Buddha said this.
After saying this, the Fortunate One, the Teacher, further said this:
“Those who do not understand suffering,
and the origin of suffering,
where suffering completely ceases,

analyzed: tat ca maggam na jānanti  dukkha upasama gāmina
translated: without remainder,🔽and the path leading to the stilling of suffering,
They are deprived of freedom of mind,
and of freedom by wisdom.
They are incapable of the final end,
they go to birth and old age.
But those who understand suffering,
and the arising of suffering,
whereby suffering completely ceases,

analyzed: asesam uparujjhati  tat ca maggam pajānanti
translated: without remainder,
and the path that leads to the stilling of suffering.
Those who have attained freedom of mind
and freedom through wisdom,
are able to put an end to this suffering,

original: na te jātijarūpagā”ti.🔽Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
analyzed: na te  ayam pi atthaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā iti me sutam ti
translated: and do not go to birth and old age again.”
This is the meaning of what the Buddha said. Thus have I heard:
